SHINE: KICKSTARTER VIDEO

Interaction | Video & Animation | Group




CHALLENGE

How can we find an audience, context, and meaningful purpose for a new or emerging technology and bridge the physical and the digital worlds through ubiquitous computing and the internet of things?


PROMPT

Students will create a 2-minute Kickstarter video that communicates the promise of an Internet of Things technology

DELIVERABLES

Final cut video with a Kickstarter pitch, video storyboards, script

SKILLS

Scripting, Storyboarding, Video Shooting and Editing, UI Design, Graphic Design, Creating surveys


RESPONSE

Working in a team of three, we created a kickstarter video for our product Shine, an IoT connected-scale alarm to help people get up easier in the mornings


Technology

We chose to focus on the connected scale after brainstorming ideas for each technology. After we decided to focus in on the scale, we created a list of times where a human comes into contact with any type of furniture or device (Appendix A1). From this, we decided to focus on the detection of humans in their beds and focus on improving wake-up routines.


Target Users

We decided to target people who have trouble getting out of their bed at their intended wake-up time. To further explore times when this occurs and test our assumptions about our target user base, we performed a survey. With # of respondents, it became clear that waking up is a real issue for all kinds of people - not just young adults and teens.



Survey and Results


From all the scenarios we brainstormed, we decided to focus on helping people get out of bed. Before moving forward, we conducted a survey to validate if people do need help for getting out of bed and see how big the market is.







Storyboards





Shot List

  1. Still shot House in the morning [5 secs ]
  2. Closed up David sleeping, shutting off the alarm (time lapse)
  3. Same angle, shutting alarm again and again
  4. Zoom out David sleeping shot
  5. Girl waking up in the morning (for the split screen)
  6. Timelapse of clock
  7. Street interview 1: old lady
  8. Street interview 2: younger male
  9. David getting up easily (from the same angle as the split screen); an empty bed
  10. Shot of David putting Shine under mattress
  11. Closed up shot of Nest, showing it turns on and starts heating
  12. [Pull Focus Shot] David back in bed, phone on bed side table: focus on mobile screen first, then music starts
  13. David getting up easily and go off the screen, empty bed
  14. Close up phone and music stops when David gets out of bed
  15. Rewind shot, David back in bed
  16. David can’t get out of bed, pulls pillow over his head to muffle sound
  17. Back to David setting up shine (shot 10)--pulls phone out from back pocket (in different shirt, standing next to bed)
  18. Over the shoulder shot of David, focus on phone, can see from background he’s in same spot as before (David interacting with app)
  19. David (happy/pleased) using phone to setup app
  20. [reused shot] David in bed with pillow over head, phone starts to ring
  21. Continued shot, David reaches for phone, starts talking on phone
  22. Changed angle of David talking on phone
  23. [reused shot?] Empty bed

Product Description:


Shine is different from other alarms in that it tunes and preps your surroundings to make the best wake up environment possible. Similar systems cost up to 300 dollars but at 50 dollars Shine will bring you a quick and highly-effective wake up system and encourage interaction between you and your loved ones at the same time. 50 dollars will get you an entire system perfect for one person in a bed of any size. If you’re a couple you can receive two Shine systems at a discounted price of 75 dollars with one installed on each side of the bed.

As aforementioned, Shine can be hooked up on the Cloud to be synced with devices such as your coffee machine or thermostat. If you are a developer who is interested in integrating specific devices with the Shine alarm system, we have opportunities for you to do so. If you are interested in joining our developer program, we will send you a device at no fee.

Join Shine, take your mornings back.



Thoughts

Interaction designers are increasingly asked to create videos as part of their practice. They use video to capture user research, often producing highlight reels toconvey points to clients and key decision makers.They use video to give form to a proposed user experience,to pitch concepts,and to gain buy-in. Finally, interaction designers increasingly make videos to summarize and introduce design work at the beginning of a presentation, for asynchronous communication and in their portfolios. Understanding how to quickly produce an appealing video—including scripting, shooting, and editing—has become as important as knowing how to interview, synthesize, wireframeand create documents.

This project involves a type of design thinking called matchmaking. Most UX projects follow a user-centered design process of studying people and inventing new things to meet their needs. Sometimes, however, companies own or control a technology that they want to exploit. To address this challenge, designers engage in matchmaking: searching for good intersections of a target set of users and the abilities of this technology.
